content.title: Intermittent Claudication
content.definition: Exercise-induced muscle pain, cramping, or fatigue in the lower extremities caused by inadequate arterial blood flow to meet metabolic demands during activity, which is relieved by rest. The term derives from Latin 'claudicare' meaning to limp.

key_concepts.description: Arterial stenosis limits blood flow reserve; at rest, oxygen delivery is adequate, but during exercise, metabolic demand exceeds supply causing anaerobic metabolism, lactate accumulation, and ischemic pain

Reproducible pain at a consistent walking distance (claudication distance), onset with activity, relief within 2-5 minutes of rest (unlike musculoskeletal pain), and ability to resume walking after rest
Buttock/hip = aortoiliac disease; Thigh = common femoral/profunda; Calf = superficial femoral/popliteal (most common); Foot = tibial disease
Aortoiliac occlusive disease presenting with: (1) bilateral buttock/thigh claudication, (2) absent/diminished femoral pulses, (3) erectile dysfunction - classic board presentation

Initial claudication distance (ICD) = distance at which pain begins; Absolute claudication distance (ACD) = distance at which patient must stop. Useful for tracking disease progression and treatment response

Relatively benign limb prognosis: only 1-2% annual progression to CLI; 5-year major amputation risk <5%. However, high cardiovascular mortality (5-year mortality 30%) due to coronary and cerebrovascular disease

Neurogenic claudication (spinal stenosis) - worse going downhill, relieved by flexion; Venous claudication - bursting quality, slow relief; Musculoskeletal - variable onset, position-dependent; Chronic compartment syndrome - athletes
ABI 0.4-0.9 typical for claudication; <0.4 suggests critical limb ischemia; Exercise ABI (post-treadmill) may unmask disease in patients with normal resting ABI

First-line treatment: smoking cessation (most important), supervised exercise therapy (SET - 30-45 min, 3x/week for 12+ weeks), risk factor modification (statins, antihypertensives, antiplatelet therapy)
Cilostazol (PDE-3 inhibitor) - improves walking distance 40-60%, contraindicated in heart failure; Pentoxifylline - minimal benefit, not recommended by guidelines
Lifestyle-limiting claudication despite optimal medical therapy (3-6 months), vocational disability, failure of supervised exercise program. Quality of life is primary driver.

definition.@value: Exercise-induced muscle pain in lower extremities caused by inadequate arterial blood flow, relieved by rest

learning_objectives: Define intermittent claudication and its pathophysiology
Correlate claudication location with level of arterial disease
Understand the relatively benign limb prognosis but high CV mortality
Apply first-line management (smoking cessation, exercise, risk reduction)
clinical_pearls: Buttock claudication + absent femoral pulses + ED = Leriche syndrome
Only 1-2% per year progress to CLI - limb prognosis is good
CV mortality is the real threat - 30% at 5 years
Supervised exercise therapy is as effective as intervention for many patients
Relief within 2-5 minutes of rest distinguishes from musculoskeletal pain
common_mistakes: Recommending intervention too early before adequate medical/exercise therapy
Focusing on limb while missing systemic atherosclerotic disease
Confusing with neurogenic claudication (stooped posture relief, worse downhill)
Forgetting cilostazol contraindication in heart failure
